speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: We often hear phrases such as, ‘dream big’ or, ‘reach for the stars’ which reflect an optimistic view of life. Are you an optimist, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: I hope so! I try to see the positive side of life, even when something bad happens.

speaker: glass-half-fullperson
text: It sounds like you’re a glass-half-full person – someone who always thinks that good things will happen.

speaker: Sam
text: How about you, Neil? Are you optimistic?

speaker: Neil
text: Look, things go wrong all the time - that’s a fact of life. Call me a pessimist if you like but I’m just being realistic.

speaker: Sam
text: Hmm, it sounds like Neil is more of a glass-half-empty person, but the truth is that the age-old debate between optimism and pessimism is more complex than we think.

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, whether you’re a sunny optimist or a gloomy pessimist may be determined more by your birthplace and your age than your attitude, as we’ll be finding out in this programme.

speaker: Sam
text: Great. I’ve got a good feeling about this, Neil!

speaker: Neil
text: But first, as usual, I have a question for you, Sam. Psychologists define optimism as an attitude which overestimates the chances of good things happening to you, while underestimating the chances of bad things occurring. So, what proportion of the British population, do you think, describe themselves as optimistic? Is it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) 20 percent?

speaker: Neil
text: b) 50 percent? or,

speaker: Neil
text: c) 80 percent?

speaker: Sam
text: I’ll choose the largest – 80 percent… but then, I’m optimistic so I would say that!

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam. We’ll find out if your optimistic answer is the correct one later in the programme. Someone who probably wouldn’t agree with you, th0ugh, is BBC World Service listener, Hannah. Hannah grew up in Germany before moving to the United States. She thinks Americans tend to be more optimistic than people back home in Germany, as she told BBC World Service programme, CrowdScience:

speaker: Debbie Downer,hypersugarcoat
text: I think the stereotypical perception of Germans is that we’re quite pessimistic and that kind of tends to come across as being a bit of a Debbie Downer, when in actuality, Germans just tend to be avid planners for all eventual negative eventualities as well… so that’s kind of us being pessimistic but actually being cautious, as opposed to for example, what I’ve notice in America that a lot of people tend to be hyper-optimistic. I’ve always admired how Americans tend to be able to sugarcoat everything.

speaker: Debbie Downer.
text: As a stereotypical pessimist, Hannah sometimes feels like a Debbie Downer. This expression is American slang for someone who makes others feel bad by focussing on the depressing aspects of things.

speaker: sugarcoat
text: Americans, on the other hand, are typically seen as optimists who tend to sugarcoat things – make things seem better than they really are.

speaker: hyper
text: According to Hannah, many Americans are hyper-optimistic. She uses the prefix hyper to say that there is too much of a certain quality. Hyper-sensitive people are too sensitive; a hyper-optimist is too optimistic.

speaker: Neil
text: Besides your country of birth, age is another consideration in the optimism debate. When we’re young we have our whole life ahead of us, and it’s easier to optimistically believe that everything’s going to be alright.

speaker: Sam
text: The belief that everything’s going to be fine is called ‘the optimism bias’. It isn’t fixed but changes as we age - something neuroscientist, Professor Tali Sharot, explained to BBC World Service programme, CrowdScience:

speaker: rock bottomgrumpy old man
text: So it’s quite high in kids and teenagers – they think, ‘Oh, everything’s going to be fine’… and then it goes down, down, down and it hits rock bottom in your midlife at which point the optimism bias is relatively small, and then it starts climbing up again and it’s quite high in the elderly population, and that goes absolutely against our view of the grumpy old man, or woman.

speaker: rock bottom
text: After starting out high in children, the optimism bias hits rock bottom – the lowest possible level – in middle age, often because of work pressures, family responsibilities or caring for elderly parents.

speaker: grumpy old man
text: But optimism seems to increase again as we get older. This is surprising as it goes against the image we have of the grumpy old man – a phrase to describe someone who complains a lot, is moody and gets easily annoyed. Optimistic women, meanwhile, can look forward to longer, healthier lives.

speaker: Neil
text: Good news for you then, Sam! But I’m sticking with my pessimism. If I anticipate things going wrong I don’t get disappointed when they do!

speaker: Sam
text: That’s actually a fairly positive way of looking at things, Neil, but I’m not sure if most people would agree with you – or maybe they would… It depends on the answer to your question…

speaker: Neil
text: Right. I asked Sam what proportion of British people describe themselves as optimistic.

speaker: Sam
text: And optimistically, I said it was c) 80 percent.

speaker: Neil
text: Which was… the correct answer!

speaker: Sam
text: Of course it was. Whether you expect good or bad things to happen to you, you’re probably right. So why not focus on the sunny side of life, Neil? That way, you’ve got nothing to lose!

speaker: glass-half-full person
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme, Sam. You’re certainly a glass-half-full person – someone with an optimistic attitude to life.

speaker: Debbie Downer
text: And you’re something of a Debbie Downer - American slang for someone who brings everyone down by talking about the negative side of things.

speaker: sugarcoat
text: If you sugarcoat something, you make it appear more positive than it really is.

speaker: hyper
text: The prefix hyper is used before an adjective to show having too much of that quality, for example hypercritical means being too critical.

speaker: rock bottom
text: If something hits rock bottom it reaches its lowest possible level.

speaker: grumpy old man
text: And finally, the phrase grumpy old man can be used to describe someone who always complains, is intolerant and gets annoyed easily… a bit like Neil!

speaker: Neil
text: Unfortunately our six minutes are up, but join us again soon for more trending topics and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English. Goodbye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye!
